Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2013 02:34PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Hi ladies, I hope you don't mind me jumping into your topic.  I finished up my reconstruction 4 weeks ago with nips being built.  Wanted to give a few suggestions for the surgeries.  1. Whatever you have packed already you won't need most of it.  Best thing to pack pull on sweats/yoga pants and a button down MENS shirt.  Most likely you will be going home with drain tubes and women's shirts are just too tight in the chest and side areas. 2. chapstick is a must. Once you get to your room your lips will be dry. 3. ribbon- once you are able to take a shower you will need to pin your drain tubes up to something so you don't have to hold them. 4. Don't do too much too soon. 5. When friends ask if they can make you dinner- say yes!   I hope all of you ladies have a speedy recovery and God bless you all!
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2013 04:43PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Enerva- I had lipo to remove for symmetry, i'm a chicken and didn't want to do fat grafting.  My PS is a big advocate of FG for upper pole symmetry.  I actually had enough upper symmetry, I had lipo again to make the cleavage area more defined.  Good luck on your preop appt and surgery.
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2013 04:28PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Enerva- yes I had drains after all 3 surgeries. After my TE surgery I had a reaction to the Alloderm my PS placed so he put drains in as a preventative. I only had them in for a week, I had 1 on each side.  The exchange surgery was so much easier than BMX and TE surgery. With my first two surgeries I took pain pills for almost a month with Exchange surgery I only took pain pills for 3 days. I was doing laundry on day 4. With my exchange surgery I also did lipo, I hurt more with the lipo than I did with the exchange.
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2013 03:14PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: swimmom- when I went in for my BMX I packed ALL the wrong things, a pullover shirt button pants a bra( I refused to want to believe I was having mine removed). I was fortunate that my hubby had a second button down shirt with him.  Oh and I forgot to mention a pillow to keep the seatbelt off of your chest.  If anyone has any questions please feel free to ask, we are all in this together.
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2013 05:03PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Dawnie-I am so sorry you are having to go through this. I was diagnosed 4 days after my 35th birthday last year. I was called back the day after my first ever mammo because the radiologist found a mass in both breasts. After doing bilateral biopsies, it came back that the left breast had cancer and the right breast was just a cyst. When talking to my BS she gave the option of lumpectomy or UMX. I told her that neither of those options was what i wanted. I wanted a BMX. So my right breast was a prophy. My downtime for my BMX was 4 weeks. My downtime was longer for my TE placement, that ended up being almost 10 weeks. My exchange surgery downtime was 3.5 weeks and I was back to work on 12/31.
Posts.Title: who has had a prophylactic mastectomy? Dawnie Chrisrenee77

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2012 08:53AM Chrisrenee77 wrote: I chose delayed recon with the help of my surgeon and my spouse. I HAD to get used to the idea that I had bc. Plus, if I had to have chemo or rads I didn't want to compromise my TE's. It is truly a personal choice for each brave woman affected by this disease to make. To me it was the same decision I had to make on deciding to do nips and tattoing. I was deadset on not doing them, then 2 weeks I changed my mind but kept it to myself. For me, I wanted to feel "normal" again, or as normal as you can be after being affected by this. Everyone has good points on their arguments and I see everyone's views. Like I said it's a tough decision to make. Karensimone- I hope you make the right decision for you. My thoughts and prayers are with you. christy
Posts.Title: just had mastectomy feeling sorry for myself karensimone Beth1951

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2012 06:55PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Hi Karen, I had my BMX in june 2012, my BS and I decided against immediate recon, because we didn't know if I would have to have chemo or rads. I was really wanting to have recon at that time, and was very upset. I don't regret the delayed reconstruction because I was able to get myself healed before I went for the next surgery. I understand about not wanting to look at yourself in the mirror post surgery. I told my husband I wanted all the mirrors in the house covered up. My husband, said that he was not going to do that and that we were going to face this head on. I have changed my mind on the final stages of recon nips and tattoos so many times. I have finally made the decision to go for the whole shebang. Cancer took my breasts and happiness for a while and with the help of my amazing dr's I'm getting it back. Make your decision for yourself not for anyone else. hugs
Posts.Title: just had mastectomy feeling sorry for myself karensimone Beth1951

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 10:51PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Bob- as the other amazing ladies on this forum have said, I am so sorry for the diagnosis your wife and you have recently received. It is the most devastating news any person could get. I was diagnosed on 5/25/12 4 days after 35th birthday. As I was told by my Breast surgeon on my initial consult, it will not change the outcome of the diagnosis iif you wait a month. The diagnosis is there, it's not going to go away. My husband, my mother and myself wen't to the BS on 5/31/12 and my BS said she had an opening for the next day if I wanted it. My husband told her to schedule it, me on the other hand being a workaholic told him absolutely not, I needed to give more notice for work. I had my bilateral mastectomy on 6/5/12. If your wife and yourself are happy with the BETTER surgeon then I would wait. If it's anxiety and the fear of spreading that's a decision unfortunately that your wife will need to make. Whatever decisions ya'll make my best wishes to ya'll. christy
Posts.Title: need one answer! Cadillac Cadillac

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 05:54PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Connie- for the day you go home. Get a large size men's button down shirt. You will not feel like raising your arms up to slide into a shirt. For the shower, buy ribbon and safety pins to attach your drain tubes too. Just a few things we did. We also hired a housekeeper for the rest of the year because I still have one more surgery to go through. Quick microwave dinners are amazing too. Good luck with your surgery!

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2013 09:01PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Amoc- I've been told that the Juzo brand is better than the Lymphadivas because it does compress better. How often are you going in for treatments?
Posts.Title: Have sleeve/gauntlet questions Amoc1973 kira

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2012 11:13PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: First off good luck with your surgery friday.my thoughts are with you. I had my bmx june 5,2012 and just had my TE's placed sept 11. As far as packing, for a shirt get a mens button down shirt. The last thing you are going to feel like doing is raising your arms up to put a shirt on. Take deep breaths and know that you are in good hands with your surgeons. If you are like me, im sure you have a wonderful support system. Lean on them to help you with all the minor and major things. If you need to talk feel free to private message me. Hugs and positive vibes christy
Posts.Title: BMX + TE scheduled Friday Oct 5th = NERVOUS!!!! JMP287 Chrisrenee77

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2013 07:07PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Amoc- I wear my sleeve/gauntlet 7 days a week from 6am-9pm. The rule of thumb i was given by my OT is if you have a bra on put your sleeve/gauntlet on when you take your bra off they come off as well.  I didn't have any issues with swelling when i started using the compression sleeves. They did tend to help.  As of a month ago my swelling has gone done almost 8% since start of therapy in March. As long as you are wearing the garments correctly all should be fine.
Posts.Title: Have sleeve/gauntlet questions Amoc1973 kira

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2013 06:47AM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Kira- I completely agree with you about the therapist not doing her job. My OT saw me twice a week for 3 months. We would do massage for and then each month take measurements to see if the swelling has gone down. Question Amoc- do you know if your therapist is LANA. Certified? There is a difference between an OT and a LANA OT. The Lana OT has gone to school and taught specific LE massage. She should have her certificates hanging near by, you might want to take a peek at them. JMO.
Posts.Title: Have sleeve/gauntlet questions Amoc1973 kira

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2012 05:33PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Nwsuburbs- when I packed for my bmx I did not pack any of the right things. I was fortunate that my hubby had packed two shirts for himself. So as I was trying to get dressed I was not able to lift my arms. So my hubby pulled out his other shirt. I wasn't the prettiest leaving the hospital but I was comfortable. And I agree about the tank tops to pin the drain tubes to. You will also want to purchase some ribbon so you can pin you drain tubes up while taking a shower. We all wish you the best tomorrow. Feel free to private message any of us as we are all in the same boat you are.
Posts.Title: BMX + TE scheduled Friday Oct 5th = NERVOUS!!!! JMP287 Chrisrenee77

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2012 02:25PM Chrisrenee77 wrote: Again so glad you came back to let us know how you are doing. I was thinking about you. I tell people breast cancer isn't for weenies. I just had my TE's placed on 9/11/12 and I am currently going through the tightness and stiffness in my back and chest. Instead of bricks I say I have two bowling balls strapped to me. I'm taking lots of Tylenol to try to get rid of mine. So glad you are doing well. The pain does eventually subside. And yes you are a superhero in the books. You've made it this far no turning back now :)
